messageBody:
Mike,

I have installed it and am using it on a small subset of a site (the other
parts of the site rely too much on JavaScript to make HTTPUnit very useful).
I like it for the very reasons you have specified, a lot more user friendly.
I think something similar would be a great extension for JUnitPerf.

Chuck

-----Original Message-----
From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2002 11:52 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Canoo WebTest


Is anyone using Canoo WebTest for automated acceptance testing of web
applications?

Having used HttpUnit and realized that it takes a lot of code to test
some basic assertions, the ability to drive HttpUnit with an XML file
sounds promising. It's also an important step towards allowing
non-programmers (e.g. customers) to easily define acceptance tests.

I'm also interested because I'm considering defining similar Ant tasks
for configuring JUnitPerf tests. Something along the lines of:

<timedTest id="1 second response time for something"
class="MyTestCase" method="testSomething" maxTime=100 />

<loadTest id="10 user load test for something"
class="MyTestCase" method="testSomething" users=10 iterations=1
/>

Or applying decoration:

<timedTest id="10 second response time for a 10 user load test"
maxTime=10000>

<loadTest id="10 user load test for something"
class="MyTestCase" method="testSomething" users=10
iterations=1 />

</timedTest>


This would alleviate having to programmatically configure various
performance tests, and allow non-programmers to define such tests.

Mike
